reviewText: My husband & I have watched this movie dozens of times over the years & it's definately our favorite Christmas movie.  It's hard to believe it was made in 1984 because the costumes, settings, automobiles,  everything, is so well done that your sure you're in 1940's mid-west  America.  It's simply a classic---not to be missed!

I saw this movie in the theater when it first came out, and I knew immediately that I wanted to own it on video.  It has so many things that make it a great movie. There is the main character, Ralphie, with his  boyhood dreams of getting the "bad guys" with a Red Ryder BB gun;  the mom who has the right mix of zaniness and motherly compassion; and  Darren McGaven is great as the dad with all kinds of eccentricities, but in  the end comes through for Ralphie.  The family is great, and the little  vignettes are hilarious.  I especially liked how they went to a Chinese  restaurant for Christmas dinner, and the rules of how to dare a friend to  stick his tongue to a frozen flag pole. This movie has so much charm,  humor, and innocent sweetness that it has become one of our family  traditions, along with Charlie Brown, the Grinch, and George Bailey.
I love this movie, especia;;y whe I recognized downtown Cleveland. The whole winter wonderland makes me long for my home in Conneaut, Ohio. Thanks for making this video available.

This movie is right up there with A Christmas Carol.  It is on TV Guide's 10 best Christmas Movies also. And It is always on television every year a million times for one reason....people love it! So add a true christmas  classic into your household, and watch it a million times!!!

My favorite of my holiday video collection.  Every time I watch it I come away with having learned something new.  Great fun for the entire family, a video you'll treasure well into the next millenium.  If you haven't yet  started a Christmas video collection; start one with this!

Once in a great while a movie comes along that pleasantly surprises us, and this is one of them.  I first saw this movie at a friend's family's house (who always had videos playing) during the holidays, and have seen it  popping up more and more every year. It deserves the overdue recognition.  This is the kind of movie where it doesn't matter where you come in, you'll  watch until it's over. Highly recommended.

This classic has become a Christmas tradition in our house.  Not to be viewed until the day after Thanksgiving, we look forward to our last bites of turkey ans stuffing.  The 24-hour marathon last Christmas Eve kept us  company while we wrapped gifts well into the night.  Except for a few swear  words (the movie would NOT be the same without them), I recommend this  movie for the entire family. It should be a part of your permanent video  collection.

... with this movie, you go back to the good old days when Peter's biggest concern (as Ralphie, the character he played in the film) was  getting "an official Red Ryder, carbine action, two-hundred shot range  model air rifle" for Christmas, despite everyone (even a  department-store Santa) telling him he'd put his eye out.
It's a flight  of fancy, incredibly funny, and a movie with which anyone who was ever a  little boy can identify.  Definitely one of those movies that needs to be  pulled out and viewed every Christmas along with classics like "It's a  Wonderful Life".
I love this movie!

Classic movie! I'm reviewing this from the perspective of a parent of a young child, to help other parents decide if it's appropriate for your kiddos.
First off my Dad always had us watch this around the holidays, and as an adult I've grown to really appreciate it. With its rating I thought, why not let my stepson watch this. He is 5. There is nothing like watching a movie with either your child or your parents to point out to you the tiny things you missed before that you wish weren't happening now.
For my kid I think it was fine, the only "oops" moments were when the narrator is talking about the leg lamp and uses the expression "electrified s*x in the window". There is also discussion and mention of the F-Bomb, but no actual F Bomb is said, so I think it's fine. It's definitely more appropriate for kids than most of the junk on regular TV these days!
The movie discusses bullying, and shows kids getting in a tussle, so it's a good way to start a conversation about that.

All in all it's a great movie for families.

The movie that keeps us entertained every Christmas has a nice Steelbook Edition for the 30th Anniversary. Some nice special features as well get transferred over from previous editions with an added "Anniversary" featurette interview.

I played this back on my Sony 4K upscaling Blu-ray player and UHD TV. It looked decent, but I think it could have looked better overall. The image was 2160p, so it was nice to see that. If there is ever a 4K version of this, I might have to pick it up. I love this movie and it brings back some good memories as it might for you as well. With the advent of new technology for making movies look and sound better, it appears WB could have paid more attention to this "classic" from the early 1980s, image wise.

Still, it's great to have this edition, as I collect the Steelbooks and find them much better than most of the plastic blue cases they distribute that have those annoying arrow "cutouts" on the left side. I have taken a picture of the steelbook itself to add to my review. I really like it.

This is the brainchild of the great comedic author & storyteller, Jean Shepard, whose hilarious short stories & droll rambling radio show kept us in stitches for many years. This movie is a combination of several of his short stories, originally published in Playboy & later collected in the book, 'Wanda Hickey's Night Of Golden Memories,' & a couple of other books, which are still available.

As funny as this movie is, it's just a sampling of his comedic genius..

The disc label was printed in black&white and it also look like it had clearly been re-shrinkwrapped. The disc and everything on it seems fine. But doubleyouteeeef. Penny pinch much? I remember seeing the TV version of a Christmas story for many years since it came out in 1983.  I cant remember seeing it on the big screen, but Im 60 now so sometimes things like that slip away, but I digress. I had the regular DVD version of this movie, and played it for my dad who is a big fan, who watches it several times each season. I thought it would be fun to have the Blu-ray version, so I ordered it thinking that it would be the full theatrical format.  While it does indeed fit the format of my 16:9 ratio TV, it seems to be cropped from the 4:3 ratio version of the regular VHS/DVD version of the movie. I found this out when I loaded both a DVD and Blu-ray in separate players and did flip back-and-forth test between views of the same scene, in several places. This is somewhat disappointing, as Id hoped to be able to see more of the action in the beloved movie. That said, the picture quality of the Blu-ray version is way better than the standard DVD. I would say though that the sound quality of the Blu-ray is a step down. Both are in mono, but the Blu-ray disc, although it has a brighter, more vivid picture, seems to have a more muted sound. I think you should know all this before you buy this disc.

You don't need to get your eyes checked, you read it right this is one of the most overrated movies Christmas or not of all time in my opinion. If you were to ask a lot of people of what they think the greatest Christmas movie is, you might hear A Christmas Story get named a lot of times. I am here to tell you that in my opinion of the movie, the main kid in the movie is a dreamer, the narration is terrible and dull. There is not much to like about this movie, and yet somehow is beloved by a lot of people not me. The movie takes place in Indiana somewhere in the 1940's, which also features some references to the Wizard of Oz, even through during the 1940's, The Wizard of Oz was not seen as the classic movie that it is today. The main kid in the movie Ralph badly wants a certain item for Christmas, and even through he doesn't pick up by the adults that he has told, that it is a bad idea. As the movie opens Ralphie (Peter Billingsley) has reveled by his adult narrator voiced by Jean Shepherd, that the item he wants the most for Christmas is a Daisy Red Ryder BB gun, and he is up in his room that he shares with his kid brother Randy (Ian Petrella), in which his Mom (Melinda Dillon) calls up to them, waiting them downstairs in 2 minutes. So he manages to get an ad for the gun in a magazine that he knows his mom reads for a hint. His dad is referred as Old Man Parker (Darren McGavin), he finally decides to tell his Mother what he wants for Christmas to which she responds "no you will shoot your eye out". One day at school during recess one of Ralphie's classmates on the worst dares of all time, he dares a boy named Flick (Scott Schwartz) to try out what his father would say happen, his tongue on the flagpole, which gets frozen stuck. The bell rings, which the kids don't know what to do quietly return to the classroom. Where the teacher Miss Shields (Tedde Moore) asks a few times where is Flick, to which a girl points out the window. The teacher goes outside, and soon there is some police, and even firemen to get him off of the flagpole. They return to the classroom, where she announces that he refused to say who put him up to the deed. But leaves a warning, Ralphie's sees a second chance, when Miss Shields assigns for the theme of a paper to be what I want for Christmas, to be turned in the next day. So he writes about what the bb gun, with even day dreams, of her rejecting the other kid's assignments until she reads his, and gives him a A+ and even rights it al over the chalkboard. He does turn it in, but when he gets his assignment back, she gave him a C+ grade, with a PS you will shoot your eye out. On more adult he decides to try, the mall Santa Claus, when the store is closing, and it is his turn in line, Santa Claus (Jeff Gillen) is in a hurry, he says "how about a nice football". And he agrees to it, since he couldn't remember what he wanted, his adult self couldn't believe, so he snaps out of it, go back up the slide, and tells Santa, and he says "you'll shoot your eye out kid". At one point receives a telegram that e won an award and will be arriving that night, the award turns out to be a lamp, that the body of the lamp is a woman's leg. I would like to know just what caring adult no matter how we'll he or she knows Ralphie, wouldn't say you'll shoot your eye out, that person would have to be a Scrooge. Tow things happen to Raphie, that would be nightmares for a lot of kids I would bet, 1 to have their mouth washed out with soap, and 2 have their item they want for Christmas to be rejected by Santa Claus. This is the movie that TBS and TNT plays a 24 hour marathon of the movie starting Christmas Eve night, and runs until Christmas Day night. I would rather watch paint dry on the wall, then to watch a marathon of this movie. If you have never seen this movie before, skip this movie, take my advice and just take a pass on this movie. But if toy still want to see it, rent it first or catch one of the many shows of it on tv on one of the two stations I have mentioned. If you like the movie, then I would recommend you to buy it, otherwise stay far away.

Not my type of movie, but probably a good watch for those who like 1940's-esque productions, or for those who watched this movie as a child. I had not watched this as a child, and saw the movie, as it had been described by an acquaintance as "a classic."  This being said, the quality of the movie (SD versus HD with playback on an iPad) was below that which I am used to in even older, rented, SD movies, such as "It's a Wonderful Life." With "A Christmas Story," the picture could be crisp at one moment, then highly blurred or "pixelated," then mildly blurred. I have watched many other SD movies on an iPad without issue, and am not sure what the problem was with this particular movie. A suggestion, if you like this type of movie (sort of like "Father Knows Best" meets "The Little Rascals"), consider viewing it in HD versus SD for a possibly better viewing experience.

Not as good as I hoped.  : (  With all the people calling it their favorite Christmas movie I thought I'd been missing out all these years.  I finally watched and was disappointed.  I thought it would be a good movie for the kids to see, but no so with the language.  I can see that there are places in the story that every kid can relate to - hoping for that special toy for Christmas, going to see Santa, dealing with bullies, the parent / child relationship and anticipating what was going to happen when "your father gets home."  There are a number of classic moments most kids go through, but the story was lacking and slow.  A lot of people like the movie, but for me not so great.  Maybe seeing it first as a child is the key, but like I said the language...  It just wasn't necessary for the movie.

I've loved everything about this movie since I first saw it in the mid-80s. I'm a child of the seventies, but it still takes me right back to my own childhood Christmases. I have it on DVD, but leave my TV on TBS each year and watch the overnight marathon between baking batches of Christmas cakes and cookies. Now, that said, I have increasingly found it necessary to change the channel during commercials. Does TBS really believe that the people who are likely to watch this are the same ones who want to see the hip-hop-ering of Christmas? As for the "new, original comdey content," what will it take for TBS to see it's own long trail of failures? The Exes? Kirstie? Conan? Samantha Bee? Angie Tribeca? What is this, "How To Fail In Television"? TBS should stick to re-running old classics like "A Christmas Story", because in the realm of new content, they haven't got a clue.

We need half stars.  Three's too many, two's not enough.  So I'm rounding up.  Not a bad movie by any means, but after 33 years of wondering what the shouting's about, I'm still wondering.  The positive reviews I've seen elsewhere seem to come from people who really, really wanted a movie that had zero sentimentality and no connection to the true meaning of Christmas.  If that's the target, this hits it.  Beyond that, it's an okay movie with no one to care about or root for (apart from Ralphie's mom, who was the only woman in the 1940s with that hairstyle).

Rubiks cubes, Trolls dolls, Mr. Potato Heads, View-Masters, Beanie Babies, our childhoods are greatly defined by the popular products we absolutely needed to own no matter what the cost. Among our present-day marketing of the hottest brands that dictate how we live, we now like every Christmas since 1983 get the chance to look back on a time before fads made their way into the childrens subconscious.

In A Christmas Story, we are taken back into the year 1940, before the effects of war altered Americas state of mind forever, and a childs greatest earning was all about stopping the bullies. The classical feel of this picture resonates with every post WWII generation with laughs aplenty that remind us of our own ridiculous family obsessions.
On the snowy Cleveland Street of Northern Indiana, all the residents young and old crowd in front of Hicbees toy store to peek in on the newest brands to add to their wish lists. The blue eyed nine-year-old in the center, Ralphie, has his sight on one thing and one thing only: a Red Ryder Carbine-Action 200 Shot Air Rifle. His younger brother, Randy, would most want a silver zeppelin, and to never eat meat loaf again. His father, known only as the Old Man, wants to keep his prized leg lamp aglow at the front of the house for all of Cleveland Street to witness, a symbol of his victories. The mother of the family wants nothing more than to keep the boys in her life in order. The shenanigans these four get wound up in are humorous to connect with, as we watch their hopes to enjoy this time of year in spite of conflicts.

Everyone has their personal moments of expression to prove how badly they want the thing they want; Ralphie will do anything to prove to his mother that he deserves something as dangerous as a BB gun, Randy refuses to fall victim to his mothers irrational scheme of over bundling him for snow treading, and the Old Man will never turn off his lamp for anything, in spite of his hectic wifes wishes.

There are never large events shown within this average family, only easily relatable moments of everyday living. Cracking a secret code from a childrens radio program or trying on your aunts embarrassing homemade pajamas may not sound like much, but watching these moments linger proves what truly makes the gears of a family spin. Its like the mind of a childthe small stuff, rather than the big stuff, are the things to get excited for.

Yet like any abruptly shifting young mind, the editing style of this feature erases any sense of narrative or fluidity. But its made up for with the consistent voiceover narration by a grown-up Ralphie who comments on what he remembers from his best Christmas ever. With this special aid, we also get a glimpse into the fantasies this nine-year-old came up with in response to the adults in his world, as inspired by genres of popular radio serials.

Its so effective, that I now feel like a part of this historic era, as looked at from the mind of a child. Although the depiction of Blacks, Asians, and Hillbillies takes out a bit of the experience, as it reflects more the racial relations of the early 1980s than the setting.

But returning us into the experience is the no-nonsense attitude that does not over glamorize the seasons commercial happiness. Set aside the jingle bells and Claymation reindeer, this special has a rude mall Santa, a poor boys tongue frozen to a flagpole, a slipping of the F-bomb from a nine-year-olds mouth, and the quarrel between hapless victims and the schoolyard bullies. Youth cant look more real than this.

In fact, the youth depiction here may as well be a little too real. As the boys always lose their sense in favor of impulsive decisions without any real punishment, it essentially teaches the mothers that boys should be boys, and we might as well just enjoy the moment. Now, does that mean that mothers should let their boys get away with lying, giving kids nosebleeds, and mocking blind people like as seen in this special? I don't think so.

Well, maybe the possessive madness in the 1940s proves how not much of anything has changed over time after all. Imagine that.

This is a movie i can watch again and again and not get sick of it. So many parts of it manage to crack me up over and over. The soap poisoning fantasy, fragile and the leg lamp, you'll shoot your eye out. This movie is relatable and I think that's what gives it staying power. Who didn't have a bully who drive him crazy or an annoying sibling or relative? Who hasn't ever wanted something and everyone seemed against you? Or had vivid fantasies about life that never came true? Ralph wants a red Ryder bb gun. He wants it more than anything. His mother is a harried housewife and his father has a potty mouth and is constantly battling the furnace. His little brother is annoying and life is never dull with Ralph's friend around. Ralph is drops every hint and uses any person he can to get his point across. I'm not a huge fan of Christmas movies but this is one I can watch again and again because it never gets less funny

We all grew up hearing our parent 's and everyone else warn us, too, about getting shot in the eye with a bb gun .My generation could certainly identify with so much in that family, that it's almost like seeing a rerun of an old family movie. It's hilarious all the way thru and so typical of that era. I hope every family , especially with kids, get a chance to see it. It's wonderful fun.

The picture quality of the Blu-Ray I don't think is any better than a DVD/HDTV version (with the caveat being that it wasn't exactly filmed with the highest quality film in the first place).
The fact I like the movie is the only reason it got 3 stars here.  The aforementioned flaws bring it down two stars.

I truly cannot say enough good things about this movie and I cannot even begin to calculate how many times I've seen it but without exaggeration it is definitely in the hundreds.

Without giving too much away this is the story of Ralphie, a young boy, who is wishing for a specific BB Gun for Christmas.  His attempts at hinting fail and he's often met with "You'll shoot your eye out".  Ralphie lives with his younger brother, mother and father.  The story takes place in Indiana around 1940 yet the movie itself was made in the 80's.  Peter Billingsly as many who lived in the 80's will remember as "Messy Marvin" in chocolate milk commercials, plays Ralphie.  This movie is a comedy.

Almost 20 years ago the cable network TNT started running A Christmas Story for 24 hours straight starting on Christmas Eve.  That tradition is now shown on both TNT and TBS and is a complete classic.  The movie is dripping with nostalgia that the young and old alike will fall in love with.  It is by far my favorite holiday movie and although it's become a tradition to leave the 24 hour marathon on of it every Christmas Eve, there is something about watching it on DVD that makes it that much more special as you do have to deal with the commercial interruptions when it's on television.  If you have seen it on TV but never uninterrupted I cannot urge you enough to pick up a copy of the DVD and watch it in all it's uninterrupted 'leg lamp' glory.  You won't be disappointed.

Is there anyone who hasn't watched Ralphie?  If there is, you are missing out.  This is a movie that the whole family will love.  A definite must to add to your movie and Christmas collection.  Why does everyone love this movie?  I think we all see some of ourselves in Ralphie.  He is a lovable mix of cuteness, insecurity, confidence, curiousity, and being afraid- the exact mix of emotions we all endured while trying to get through that most wonderful and awful thing called adolescence.  If you haven't watched this movie, do it now.  Don't wait till Christmas!

This is possibly the best and funniest representation of an average Midwest family's Christmas with all the eccentricities relatives bring to the event.

It's an enduring tale of a young boy's ardent desires to own a Red Rider BB gun and the frustrations of being told "you're too young, it's too dangerous".  In the 50's, this was pretty much the end-all, be-all thing for a boy - or a girl as Dale Evans could shoot as well as the guys.  This is also when you could collect points for buying comic books and/or sell items from them for more points to order real chemistry sets, even master ones you could create and blow things up!

It's a tale of a bye gone era with a type of innocence we'll never see again.  Information was not so easily obtained, kids stayed kids for far longer than they do today.

I highly recommend watching it several times, as you'll catch something different just about every time.

I am admittedly biased, but I LOVE this movie.  This is one of the only movies I have ever seen that captured the way the world really looks in the eyes of a child.  The perception of bullies, peer pressure (kid who was double dog dared to put his tongue on a freezing flag pole), and the feeling that getting something through the mail as a kid authenticates you in the world.  But to be clear, this is not a smarmy tiptoe through childhood.  This is a comedy, from beginning to end.  The sadistic Santa that steps on Ralphie's face to get him to go down the slide, the bunny outfit that Ralphie had to wear because one of his relatives made it for him, Darren McGavin's constant battles with his furnace, the Chinese restaurant they had to go to on Christmas because the neighbor's dogs ate the thanksgiving turkey.  Pure magic.......

A Christmas Story is a classic American Christmas tale.  A young boy schemes to get his mitts on a Red Ryder BB Gun, the Holy Grail of Christmas gifts for any young boy.  Pure poetry.  Jean Shepherd does a masterful job of writing and narrating.  Absolutely perfect!  The cast is top-notch from top to bottom and through and through.

Peter Billingsley plays the role of Ralph to perfection.  The round face, the scheming look, and the gang of pals is pure Americana.

Every year my wife puts together a "Christmas Chain".  Each link in the chain is made of paper and lists a family activity or event for every day from 1 December through Christmas Eve.  One of the family favorites is "Fa-ra-ra-ra-ra".  On that day we go out and eat Chinese food, then go home and watch "A Christmas Story."  We only watch it once a year, for that activity.  By the time we watch it again it's fun and fresh.  And the movie quotes, oh man!  They are rich!

Here are a few favorites:
"My father wove a tapestry of obscenity that as far as we know is still hovering someplace over Lake Michigan."
"You'll poke your eye out, kid!"
"A plus, plus, plus, plus."
"Maybe Miss Shields would excuse me from theme writing for the rest of my natural life!"
"But what is it?...It's a MAJOR AWARD."
"We don't want to waste electricity!"
and
"I had pulled it off!"
...among many, many others.

OK, I know I'm going to get some people calling me "un-American" for only giving this film three stars, but it's never quite appealed to me like some of the other classics do.

Ralphie, the main character, is actually quite shallow. Most of the film revolves around his desire for a BB gun, which almost becomes unhealthy. He's not likable in the way Kevin is in Home Alone. Kevin has a big personality, is faced with incredible tasks, and shows the creative genius of his 8 year old self. Ralphie is just an average kid who deals with a school bully and a mother who doesn't want to get him a BB gun over fears of eye injuries. True, he may be more relatable for some people, but he just seems like a stock character.

There are definitely some classic scenes in this movie, but imagine how much better it would have been if Ralphie had a little more personality or if there was a great supporting character by his side. The dysfunctional family does add some dimensionality to things, but even in their best scenes, they don't really add any deep plot twists. Speaking of supporting characters, the teacher is one of the better ones, but the Santa Claus scene seems a bit of a stretch for the 1940 setting. Sure, he may have cautioned about shooting an eye out, but I doubt any department store would have had a setup as elaborate as the one in the film (which works great for effect, but not accuracy).

The entire movie just seems like someone's diary from Christmas, played out as a film, without a good movie plot. There are some funny moments, but to me, this isn't so much as "story" as it as a "sequence of events" which just so happen to have a desire for a particular BB gun in common to link them together. It isn't a movie I make a point to watch at Christmas, but it is at least palatable and has a few funny moments.

One thing to point out--the movie wasn't actually a big success when it first came out. It seems as though it became an acquired taste in American culture. I'm curious to see what the people who actually saw it in 1983 thought of it.

Revisiting "A Christmas Story" (1983) is akin to a yuletide family reunion without the slightest trace of cynicism or mawkishness. An impossible movie to dislike thanks to a winning cast, Bob Clark's effortless direction and Jean Shepherd's integral narration. The attention to nostalgic detail is nothing short of sublime. Along with its status as a holiday perennial, "A Christmas Story" deserves recognition as a classic film that gets better with each passing year.

My family and I have enjoyed this film every Christmas season for years.  A couple of years ago I purchased the Blu Ray version so we could watch it at our convenience.  The only reason I'm rating it at four stars instead of five has to do with its closed captioning.  We have an adult relative who is deaf, so for the first time we displayed the closed captioning as we watched the film this year.  We had several children in the room and we were surprised and disappointed to see very explicit curse words running across the bottom of the screen, especially in those scenes when Darren McGavin was dealing with his furnace and everything else that annoyed him.  When you're listening to the dialogue, you don't catch the actual words because he mumbles them, but the people who did the captioning apparently decided to go with the script, or perhaps what they assumed he was saying.  I still love the film, but I suggest that parents of children avoid the captioning, unless of course it isn't a big deal for you.

The extra bonus features alone are worth picking up this release.  The 20 minute documentary about the house is great.  2 more extras that were on the 20th anniversary DVD set (but were not on the previous Blu-ray release) are back: Audio of Jean Shepherd reading two of the stories from his book "In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash".  All other extras from the previous Blu-ray release are still here, as well as a DVD copy of the film.  Wrap all this up in an attractive steelbook case and you've got a wonderful gift.  I don't know if anyone else noticed but the artwork on the inside of the case shows the famous flagpole scene, oddly there are two Flicks, one stuck to the flagpole, the other one standing with Ralphie and Schwartz looking in awe.  Weird.

This is one of the all-time classics for any season. "It's a major award."
What a lot of people don't know is that the narrator, Jean Shepherd, also wrote all of the short stories that make up the movie. The Bumpus Hounds is a story, Scut Farcus is another, lady's leg is another... All put together to make a great movie.
I highly recommend the books he has written with those stories: In God We Trust and Wanda Hickey. Good stuff.
My favorite line that didn't make the movie is, as Dad tried to glue the lamp, "he uses the kind of glue they use to put together exploded locomotives." The imagery is priceless.

A Christmas Story is a Christmas comedy classic that can be enjoyed by the entire family. Set in the 1940s in the fictional Indiana town of Hohman, this story follows the main character, 9 year old Ralphie Parker and his family, through the Christmas holidays. Ralphies main quest this year is to receive the one thing he truly desires for Christmas  a Red Rider Range 200 Shot BB Gun!

This move was originally released in 1983 and my entire family has enjoyed watching this adorable Christmas-themed story year after year. I am very happy to be able to add it to our DVD collection. I did NOT receive this product for a promotional discounted price, nor at no cost, in exchange for this review. I purchased this item at the regular price at which it was offered and it will be for personal use. All statements made in this review in regard to this product, represent my own genuine and honest opinions.

You know, I might not passionately hate this movie if it weren't for the folloing: Ralphie gets stressed trying to help his dad with a flat tire. Ralphie says the same swear word he's always heard his dad use. His mom washed his mouth out with soap and insists that he reveal who he learned taht word from (Hello.) Ralphie is forced to name a friend, since his mom is clearly living in denial. We hear the friend getting beaten over the phone, wailing, "What did I do? What did I do?" Well, he didn't do anything. (Not that it would really be OK if he had.)

And that's supposed to be family-oriented comedy?

If a movie is judged purely on the number of times people watch it, then "A Christmas Story" has to be one of the best movies ever made.  Chock full of original and funny story ideas and great lines, it is a delight from beginning to end.

"A Christmas Story" is a tale of a normal American family (from around 1940) in the days leading up to Christmas ... as seen through the eyes of a 9 year-old boy (Ralphie).  Ralphie wants a BB gun for Christmas, but his mom, his teacher ... and even Santa Claus ... are against the idea.  Undeterred, he never gives up his hope, and when he does finally get "the best Christmas present that I had ever received ... or would ever receive"  we, the audience,  rejoice in his triumph.

Excellently written, "A Christmas Story" is based on the childhood memories of writer and radio talk show host Jean Shepherd ... who co-wrote the movie's script.  Mr. Shepherd also narrates the movie ... with the gusto and fun of the 9 year-old still inside him ... and has a cameo in the film as well (as the man who chides Ralphie in the department store, "Hey kid.  Where do you think you're going?")

The casting was perfect.  Peter Billingsley is a surprisingly excellent little actor.  He manages subtleties that are beyond the range of most performers.  Melinda Dillon is very good as the mom. Darren McGavin is extremely entertaining and funny as the impatient dad.  Tedde Moore is simply excellent as Ralphie's teacher Miss Shields.  And all the kids in the movie are enjoyably believable.

Some serious money was spent on the making of this movie. Notice the Christmas parade scene or the department store scene, and imagine creating them ... from scratch.  But it is the charm of "A Christmas Story" that gives it its enduring appeal.  The dreams and imagination and adventures of this young boy pull us into this movie ... and make us want to stay there.

I don't know if it's the portrayal of his parents, or the insight into the life of a young boy that we can all relate to, but this movie simply never gets old.  Poor Ralphie's struggle to get the best Christmas present ever is very, very real.  Frought with hope, dashed dreams, and family dilemmas, this piece of cinema gold keeps delivering!

It's a Christmas tradition in our house to watch this movie on Christmas Eve before everyone goes to bed (well, except the parents of course) and I can tell you that I'll be carrying that tradition into my own family someday.

Let me clarify....I can handle a movie with a few bad words in it but what I especially can't stand is a CHIRSTMAS movie having language like this one did AND making the children in the movie say them! How low can you go!  Our children are exposed to enough of this stuff in everyday life little own letting our littlest ones think that it is ok at such a young age!! One of the greatest Christmas films ever, and completely rewatchable at any age. The older I get, and the more often I view this, the more I see how perfectly Darren McGavin nails to role as the dad in the story, his furious reaction to the broken furnace, the wacky lamp and even his final, determined dinner plans following the country dogs running off with the turkey. There's just so much to enjoy about this film that a review just can't do justice. The content is tame, although there is a creepy bully (complete with appropriate 'Peter and the Wolf' sountrack music) and a brief fight scene with a bloody nose, but that's probably the single worst part (other than a brief, near-profanity sequence that adults will pick up that's over the heads of most kids.) It's a very silly film and a lot of fun for the family.

I'm ten. I made a huge mistake to watch it. I watched this in my class and it was horrible. Most of the bad reviews are on the DVD not working. I only could watch the beginning. I HATE THIS MOVIE. A Christmas story has TERRIBLE WORDS!!!!!!!!!!!! You think horror movies are nerve wreaking, but the people do things that make me feel beyond terrified and get me to a point of screaming in the movie. First, Raphie's younger brother screams and cries because his mommy puts on too much winter stuff on him and he cries "I can't move my arms!", and the mom ignores him. My classmates and others found it funny, but that made my tummy sink and I had to keel in order to keep from screaming and throwing up at the same time. I couldn't see the part where a boy sticks his tongue on a wood pole. When I thought it was safe, the bullying started. I hid in the girl's bathroom. I also felt sick when an elf forcefully placed Raphie's younger brother on Santa's lap and Santa scared him by loudly saying "Ho,Ho, Ho." I had to sit out the rest of the movie. WARNER BROS AND BOB CLARK, HOW DARE YOU MADE A HORRIBLE MOVIE!!!!!BAD LANGUAGE AND TERRIFYING PARTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Want to know what A Christmas story is for!? ADULTS!!!!!!!!!!NOT FOR KIDS!!!!!!!!!!! BOOOOOO

Holds up to repeated semi-annual viewings, the characters are nicely over-the-top, characterized truly from a kid's point of view. Nostalgia with a nice twist, you might recognize yourself or a situation whether alive during this era or not. This familiarity is how A Christmas Story has accrued its classic status.
I remember when it was first released and the timing was awkward, it was out a couple of weeks too soon before Christmas to gain a huge holiday audience. Nonetheless as word got around over the years it gained staus as a viewing tradition for many families. Not easy to compete with It's A Wonderful Life but this one is right up there. Solid storytelling and period design is spot on.
From a couple of discrepancies in the dated items shown in the film (clothes, decoder rings, newspapers, sports trades) there is some debate as to what year this story is "supposed" to have taken place. But I chose to think that it's pre-war (or even post war), at any rate a time of innocence for the kids. It's their fantasy and it becomes ours, the desire for a particular Christmas gift being the most important thing in the world without feeling guilty for posessing that degree of materialism. It's good to enjoy that age again and this film takes us there superbly and in sublime fashion.

(Talk to text) If you are reading this review it is likely because you have had a prior experience with this wonderful movie. In our family we have a very traditional way of approaching the Christmas season. As Christmas draws near the requirements for being our families video of the night becomes more and more stringent. For example, movies such as Rudolph the red nose reindeer and frosty, while good movies, are reserved for the first week of December. There are still some really great movies that are out there and will likely push this movie back to the week prior to Christmas however that puts it in our top eight movies for the holiday season. Five stars all the way great acting, Great production great direction great feel. All-around a wonderful Christmas story perhaps thats why they call it a Christmas story. Enjoy

Great Holiday classic.  A very good rendition of life in the late 1940s.  I and my brothers wore winter snow suits exactly like the ones worn by Ralphie and his brother in this movie, although we wore them in the early 1950s.  I remember friends' houses that were heated with coal furnaces and the noise and dirt associated with them.  There are some classic lines and props in this well-acted and well-written screenplay.  Oh, and everytime I or my brothers asked for a BB gun, we were told "you'll shoot someone's eye out", what a classic line.
A perfect holiday gift
Such a fun Christmas movie - great for the entire family!

The quintessential Christmas classic that is not really that old.  I remember seeing my father locked into this movie when I was younger and still living at home.  He didn't laugh at everything but it was obvious that this movie really touched the Christmas spirit within him.  Eventually, I took the time to watch it and it found the same soft spot in my Christmas heart as his.  Even though we didn't live in the midwest, there are plenty of Christmas traditions that every family from the Boomer and Greatest Generation can identify with.  Presently, I am adamant about watching this movie at least once during this joyous season but I often watch it multiple times.  It's just one of those kind of movies, like a catchy tune, that I can watch over and over again and continue to appreciate it as much as the last time.  This was the first time I watched it in HD on our new 65" big screen.  The resolution, color and depth is astonishing.  It was like being right in the scenes with them.  Highly recommended.

More than 2600 reviews!  How does one get useful information here about a specific product when amazon lumps together reviews of EVERY VERSION ever released, written over a span of decades???  We all know the movie itself and its many charms, and I would guess that the majority of folks shopping for A Christmas Story already like/love/LOVE it.  So I will confine my comments to one specific product: The 2008 "Ultimate Collector's Edition", which ships in a metal canister and includes a string of "leg lamp lights" along with the Blu-ray disc.  First, the disc: As a few others have pointed out, there's not much new here, compared with earlier DVD releases--just a commentary track, a few trailers and recycled special features from the 20th anniversary (2003) DVD release (still in standard definition).  The main feature is a mediocre transfer with way more digital artifacts than should be present in an HD Blu-ray release.  Still, I doubt that most viewers would notice or care--it's a nostalgia-soaked holiday feel-good movie, after all.  The leg lamp lights are actually pretty well done--ten mini leg lamps about 3-3/4" tall that stretch out to nearly ten feet.  Best of all, the legs themselves radiate "the soft glow of electric sex" as Jean Shepherd would have wanted.  As for the tin, it's a functional canister which can hold things, such as holiday baked goodies; but would it have killed them to print some images from the movie on the sides and back?  (The decorative borders wrap around, but frame nothing--just more green metal.)  I'm withholding one star for the shamelessly "half-fast" execution, but of course, the movie itself rates a big five.  Note: Recently this set has been offered for much less than standalone sets of leg lamp lights on amazon, so you could buy it for the lights and get the movie & tin as a bonus.  Ho, ho, ho!

This was my first real viewing (start to finish) of the movie. It's worth a watch if you've never seen it. Not sure if it's one to watch every year, however (as I do  the 1951 "A Christmas Carol" with Alastair Sim as Scrooge, or "It's A Wonderful Life" with Jimmy Stewart & Donna Reed).

There are some amusing moments - and one sight gag (a la Keystone Cops) that is overused. For me, the intrigue of this movie was less about Ralphie (the main character) and more about the eccentric father and how diametrically opposed the mother was. How in the heck did THESE two hook up? Given that, the movie takes a somewhat surprising but very warm, heartfelt turn - and you're left feeling that all is right with the world.

OK, so the title of this review is a bit harsh, but I think I got ripped off...
I give this 3 Stars. The movie is a classic worth 5 stars on it's own, but you expect a little more from an HD Anniversary edition.
Pros:

+ Comes with Digital (UV) and DVD copy (one or both are standard these days with Blu-Ray discs)
+ Nice tin case

Cons:

- Mono DTS Sound (Instead of 2, 6, or 8 audio channels, it has one... but it has a REALLY high bitrate, so they thought that was good enough)
- No noticeable visual improvement over the DVD in this same box...

In Short... Don't get this, get the DVD as cheap as you can get it, and wait until someone actually takes the short amount of time needed to remaster this movie correctly. There is absolutely NO noticeable difference between the Blu Ray and the DVD in my Blu-ray player.

Most of the time, there is a night and day difference when watching a DVD vs Blu Ray, even when using an up-converting DVD player (which my Blu-Ray player does with DVDs)... This is an exception... I honestly think they just copied it from a DVD using some up-conversion software... 30th Anniversary Blu Ray? not worth it.

Edit:
Since writing this review, I have done a few shot-to-shot comparisons of the BluRay vs DVD... The BluRay is slightly crisper, but not much. You really have to look at tiny details to see it, but most of the screen looks identical. Having seen several older movies that have been correctly remastered for BluRay, this is a disappointment in comparison... I still think it's worth waiting and living with the DVD copy unless you can find the BluRay version cheap.

Call me a Scrooge if you want, but this is absolutely, positively, the biggest waste of time I've ever forced myself to sit through! Honestly, if I hadn't paid $3.99 to rent it in HD, I NEVER would have sat through it.

Although the movie takes place a few years before I was born, I could relate to a lot of what was going on. Yeah yeah, I heard the "Don't shoot your eye out!" warnings, myself. But what's so funny about that? Getting your tongue stuck to the flagpole? That was perhaps made sort of funny in Dumb and Dumberwhich, come to think of it, describes this movie PERFECTLY!

The parents were caricatures, and the seemingly endless fast-motion chases by the bullies... well, let's say it just bored me the first time and made me roll my eyes every other time.

DON'T even compare this with any of the real Christmas classics from the 1940s. As sappy as those are, at least they have class... Something this movie will never have!

I'm an avid movie fan, and I'm not here to trash all American-made movies and bemoan the sad state of Hollywood movies today. But after reading dozens of glowing reviews, I decided to keep an open mind and try watching it. Won't make that mistake again. Ever. Promise.

I understand why it's so popular:  It takes Baby Boomers back to their nostalgic childhoods, in an exaggerated and melodramatic way.  My criticism of it is that it's rather crass.  It's not got sleazy/sexual humor or very much cussing, but it makes Christmas into a pop culture experience, and leaves out not only Jesus but even His messages of generosity and humility, which most non-religious Christmas stories such as How the Grinch Stole Christmas have.  It's comedic fluff without any message of substance.  I feel like it trivializes Christmas.  It has some really funny stuff in it, though, so I like it somewhat.

A Christmas Story is the best Holiday movie ever made, but you already knew that. This is a review of the Ultimate Collector's Edition Blu-ray (2008). The picture and sound quality are fine (adequate, but not great). My main gripe is with the product description on Amazon. It claims that this version of the blu-ray contains special features that it does not in fact contain. The following special features are included on this disc:
Commentary with Peter Billingsley and director/co-writer Bob Clark
20th Anniversary Documentary Another Christmas Story
Daisy Red Rider: A History Featurette
Get a Leg Up Featurette
Script Pages
Theatrical Trailer
The following are the special features that Amazon claims are included on this disc, but are not:
Original readings by Jean Shepard, author and voice narrator of A Christmas Story
Triple Dog Dare Interactive Trivia
Decoder Match Challenge
Hidden Presents
I don't know which DVD/Blu-ray version contains these features, if any, and Amazon apparently doesn't either.
Amazon makes deciding which DVD/Blu-ray version of a movie to buy difficult because it combines all of the reviews for that movie together and displays them all for each different version. If the product page for the Ultimate Collector's Edition Blu-ray only displayed reviews for the Ultimate Collector's Edition Blu-ray, making the decision to buy it would be a lot easier. Chances are that someone buying a movie has already seen it and likes it, so a review of the VHS version saying the movie is awesome does not help someone looking to buy a Blu-ray version of the movie. Accurate details about picture/sound quality and special features, on the other hand, would be helpful.

A Christmas Story, 1983 film

The film begins in winter, children await Christmas. The cars suggest the 1930s. Kids view a department store window. Ralphie sees the one toy he wants: a Red Ryder BB gun. People listen to "The Lone Ranger". Mother knows there is danger with such a toy. [Ralphie's fantasies reflect the cowboy movies of the 1930s.] Remember those snow suits? Would they act up in class? Would they stick out their tongue? What do they want for Christmas? What did his Dad win? How do the piggies eat? What an artistic lamp? They don't make them like that anymore! Remember 15 minute radio programs? Remember tires that often went flat? Getting your mouth washed out with soap? [Was 'Lava' worse than 'Lifebuoy'?] "A crummy commercial!"

Ralph's father fights with the furnace. His Mom has an accident with that lamp. Ralphie learns about peaceful coexistence in the alley. Can he ask Santa for that BB gun? We see an elaborate Christmas parade from that era. Santa Claus warns him about that BB gun. Christmas arrives, Santa left a load of toys. Aunt Clara sent a special gift for Ralphie. Isn't it cute? "What's that behind the desk?" Ralphie learns that a BB gun is dangerous when not properly supervised. [A metal backing ricochets towards the shooter.] An open door is dangerous when there are hungry dogs outside. Where can they find a restaurant on Christmas Day? They'll always remember that day.

Jean Shephard had a late-night radio show from the late 1950s to the late 1970s. He would reminisce about the days of yesteryear, as in this film. He wrote books during this era. The fact that he lost an eye in childhood was a secret. You can surmise the cause. Any gun is a danger when mishandled by an inexperienced child. BB air guns were originally designed as a toy or tool for adults or responsible children. If you remember another version you'll know they were more explicit about the damage to the eyeglasses. This film shows how commercials to children are used to control buying by adults.

Jean Shephard in fact lost an eye by a ricochet from his BB gun! He was an amateur radio operator. How did he get into the Army with a glass eye? He memorized the chart and could "see" with his glass eye!

What can one say about this classic, that has not already been said?  We'll how about the fact that I did not like it at first. From a young age (3) I realized I did not like braty whiny kids. Born in the 70's, I grew up with this movie, but never really watched it until I was in my late 20's.

 I had always stayed away from it because it seemed that every time the main star opened his mouth, he was whining about that damn BB Gun.  It was not until I got married and my husband forced me to watch it one year that I realized it was not all that bad.  I still can't stand whiny kids, so the fact that I can watch it with out tearing my hair out says something.

The whole story was good, from start to finish. The characters are lively and well played.  The story flows without any downtime AND this could really be your family or a family that you grew up with.  No matter your station in life, wether you are rich or poor as a church mouse, you will be able to relate in one way or the other.

 I wish all movies made you feel this way.  In a time where we are losing wholesome family movies, it's refreshing to step back in time and enjoy that family unity once more.  This is definitely a "gather the whole family" movie.  A cult classic to be shared with all.  I now watch it every year (but no more than two times).

The prevalence of guns and bullies in this movie is already starting to work against it as a holiday classic. You don't see it as much as you used to around the holidays, and I don't think it's just because people are tried of watching 24/7 on WTBS during Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.

Which is a shame, because I don't think that the movie in any way endorses a gun culture among kids, though I do think that the light-hearted take on bullying is a little hard to take. But for the most part, I admire how director Bob Clark created a very credible recreation of the time in which he confronts the realities of poverty among the working classes. He also targets how merchandisers have cheapened Christmas with advertising. Yet Christmas emerges unscathed from the movie seeming just as fresh and sacred as ever.

The movie has so much going for it that I'm hoping everything that's good in it will survive the current national climate of gun violence and bullying in our schools. Somehow, I doubt it.

I watch this every year. Its the best!!!! It simply doesn't feel like the holidays without it. Although, it doesn't have to be Christmas time to enjoy it. It's funny & relatable. This is a collection of tales as they are recollected by a person thinking back on their childhood one Christmas. It has all the exaggerations with its ups and downs. Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsley) spots a "Daisy Brand Red-Ryder BB" 200-shot Carbine with compass, in the window of a story and fantasizes on how to get it for Christmas. Will he succeed? And if so will he shoot his eye out? I had one of those Davie Crocket hats when I was a kid. There were lots of other items and actions that I could relate to. However my wife likes the watering method used by Melinda Dillon (mother) around the trophy. And she likes the way the mother conserved electricity by turning it off. I could see her snickering through the corner of my eye. I am not sure I should have bought this movie. It may prove fatal to any window plans. The sequel of "A Christmas Story" ("It Runs in the Family" [1994]) lacks a lot of the originality of this one. My Summer Story

I spent Christmas with my parents and assumed they had the 24 Hours of A Christmas Story, but they no longer had access to that channel. And I didn't bring my DVD with me - total sadness. Brings me back to when I was a kid.  So much In the movie reminds me of my childhood.  From the bully with the yellow eyes and being chased down the alley, the Palmolive soap to wash your mouth out (which we got frequently), the snow suit where the little brother couldn't put his arms down (my sister had that red snow suit and the same problem, she walked to school with her arms in the air. Ha! She did look like she was going to pop), the dad who cussed at the furnace (how well I remember that), laying in all that Christmas wrap at the end of the frenzied unwrapping and hearing Dad say to Mama: "My, gosh, would you look at all that mess!"  I remember the meatloaf, mashed potatoes, the aroma of Mama's cooking drifting outside from time to time, and hearing the dogs barking away.  It kind of saddens me to watch it, not because it isn't a wonderful movie, but because I miss some of my growing up years, and this movie takes me back in time to the good and not so good parts of it.  Oh, and last but not least, the 'Red Ryder BB Gun', my brother had to have one, and the words of my Mama: "You'll shoot your eye out!"  Thanks for the memories Christmas Story, when I miss the days back when, I turn this on and for a brief moment am transported back to when things weren't so bad, or perhaps didn't seem to be..  Great movie, if and when it wears out, I will get another!

I saw this as a teenager in the theaters on a whim and was very pleasantly surprised; it has become a family tradition ever since we got it on video many years later.  Based on the works of Jean Shepard, it is very faithful to the source material (he even narrates) - even if some of the stories are not originally related to Christmas (the Bumpkiss hounds actually eat the Easter ham in Shepard's book) but as a whole the collected stories are believable, poignant, and funny.

Of course, EVERYONE has seen this by now, so you know what I'm talking about.  If you're one of the 15 or so people in America who haven't seen it, do yourself a favor and correct that as soon as you can.  Also, look into getting your hands on Jean Shepard's books as well - also highly enjoyable and recommended.

There is a strong thread of truth that goes through all aspects of the movie and the characterization of Ralphie's parents, both tough and very loving, is especially enchanting. For laughs, love and a particular Christmas spirit this movie cannot be beat.

I grew up  in the era this film is set. Ralphie could have been me, and Darren Mc Gavin, he Father, could have been mine. He was a Ford man, and would defend his choice of car like Mc Gavin loved his Oldsmobile's.  His salty language was used around the house, much to my mothers' distressed and when I let one epitaph lose, I was given the lifebuoy soap treatment. And she wondered where I had heard it?  My mom didn't want me to get a Red Ryder BB gun, and used the same dialog "you'll shoot your eye out".  I had a younger brother who wouldn't eat his vegetables, and would stick them anywhere except his mouth.  My Dad was an expert at fixing things, and somehow thought swearing helped. One of my  friends actually was talked into sticky his tongue on a pole in winter. Our Christmas tree had those 7 watt bulbs that could burn down a tree if the extension plug didn't burst into a "blue ozone" before. The film is set in a northern city like where I grew up.  We would go to downtown and look into the Christmas displays. It was one of our rituals that have been lost. And since most of us did not get toys, except for Christmas, it was more special than today. Like most grandparents of my generation, we have spoiled them, and Christmas just isn't like it was in my time as a child.
Classic Christmas comedy, my kids asked if it was really that funny when we were growing up. And it was.
We watch from 7:00 p.m. on Christmas Eve until 7:00 p.m. on Christmas Day every year.  It stays on all night long. It wouldn't be the same without it!

This movie was made for my generation yet somehow I had not seen it until today, thirty years after its release.  It is very much hyped as one of the best Christmas films of all time and amazingly funny.  The reality is that it neither pans out as humorous nor truly a Christmas film.  The acting is fine and the story is reasonably written but it is devoid of the sort of moments and laughs that make a supposedly memorable film memorable.  It is not a not-my-taste issue but simply, not a particularly good movie.  It is quite simply boring.  If not for the few elements of nostalgia, it would be of absolutely no value whatsoever.  It would seem that this is yet another example of the simpleness of people who prefer to mindlessly adhere to hype rather than make independent evaluations as if somehow dissenting would be a source of personal embarrassment.  Furthermore, for a so-called wholesome family film, there is a fair amount of profanity in it to which I would choose not to expose young children.

This movie is a true classic.  The characters are eternally memorable from the dazed lead character Ralphie to the bully Farkus, from smart a$$ed friend Flick to the witchy school marm (can you imagine giving an a homework assignment during Christmas season?), and of course anyone who has raised kids can appreciate the bedraggled parents of Ralphie and his kid brother Randy who desperately attempt to survive the holiday season.

There are classic memorable scenes as well, including dinner in a Chinese restaurant with waiters attempting to sing Christmas carols in broken English.  I can no longer hear "ho ho ho!" without hearing in my head the way that the Santa in A Christmas Story says it.

My favorite Christmas story.  It's just not Christmas until I've seen A Christmas Story,  I could watch it over and over.  LOVE IT !

An instant holiday classic when it came out, it still holds up as one of the best Christmas movies of all time. An iconic tale of a boy and his dreams - it captures the essence of being a child and longing for that one gift that will make this Christmas the best Christmas ever! This movie is classic.  I can't go without seeing it every Christmas season.  You'll shoot you're eye out.  Daddy's gonna kill Ralphie.  I can't put my arms down.  Frag-i-l-e, it must be italian.  Yellow eyes he had yellow eyes.  and finally... Fuuuuuudge.
Funniest movie about Christmas ever!  This movie is entertaining and appropriate for all family members.  A keeper for generations to come!
The original,  still the best Christmas movie of all time. So many classic scenes if you haven't watched this movie yet you missing out.

I give this movie a 5 star rating, simply because I love hearing Ralphie imagining his dreams of what he wants for Christmas, as well as a boy just growing up, doing things I feel little boys anticipated during this time period. One of my favorite parts is where he finally receives his Ovaltine de-coder in the mail... things like this actually did happen back then! Ralphie's father is somewhat self-centered, but when Ralphie gets his BB gun, you really understand how he did care about others, rather than just himself. There's a few language issues, which I wish substitutes could have been used to get the message across - so, I recommend parents viewing the movie first to make sure it's appropriate for your child. I feel many people enjoy this movie, and it just gets better over the years I've watched it... noticing things I missed before. To me, it's a bit exaggerated on some things that make for a good laugh, and the family seems a little "different" - but, all in all- it's probably more like the old days than not! Check it out - hopefully, you can write a better review than me!

This is particularly meaningful for those of us who were actually kids during that time.  It's a family favorite ever since our boys went to the movie theater and saw it with their dad, who had a red rider bb gun.

This is a good family movie.  It is great to watch when the weather outside keeps you in the house.
A holiday must-have in my house.  Wouldn't be Christmas without it.  Now we can watch this without all the commercials.

This Is A Great Movie That My Family And I Enjoy Watching Every Year !

Terrific story for all ages. I watched it with my 7-year old daughter and we both had a blast laughing!

I had never seen this movie but had heard so much about it that I bought it on a whim. It is a cute movie but a bit overhyped. Parts of it are very funny but the funniest scenes are the ones you have seen in reviews -the tounge on the frozen lamp post and the pink bunny pj's. I am glad I saw it but I won't watch it every year

This is as funny as a Lampoon Christmas.  I love this movie and laugh so hard each time I see it!  My children in their late 30's still remember seeing this as kids and can still quote the main lines.  I don't need or want to see a sad, sentimental movie to get the idea of the season.  This is a great movie to remind of us all the things in our lives and to look at them with a great sense of humor.  It is the best.

Ralphie speaks for all those that had to negotiate the complex course of those pre-teen years.  I see myself, as a kid, feeling as Ralphie does, facing similar issues and trying to find my way through a maze.  Years later it all seems innocent and humorous but, at the time, we thought otherwise.  A great movie for any willing to be transported to their youth.

A Christmas Story is my #1 favorite Christmas movie. It is 1940s, Ralphie Parker (Billingsley) had a Christmas wish: a Red Ryder 200-shot Carbine Action Air Rifle BB Gun which is very popular to children. His overprotective mom (Dillon), his foul mouthed father (McGavin), and many adults will say the same warning "you will shoot your eye out" to him. Ralphie had many hilarious situations to get his wish granted. I love this movie and I promise whenever you want to watch a Christmas film with your family, this film is perfect and a recommend.

My blu-ray arrived today, and I was very excited to watch it, as this is a daily movie for our family during the Christmas season...and the english version of the blu-ray does not play.  Spanish versions both worked fine, but the english on the main feature was absolutely silent.  I did play the DVD disk and it worked, and the bonus features worked fine, so I wonder if I somehow got a defective disk.  Amazon is overnighting me a replacement so we'll see if that fixes the problem or if it remains on the new disk.

As it turned out, I needed to change a setting on my new Blu-ray player and then I had perfect audio.  Both discs had the same problem.  After doing trouble shooting with Samsung, got the blu-ray doing what it needed to, this is top notch!
It's kind of a classic. A classic on Blue-Ray. I don't know what else you need to know... it's awesome.

Being born in 1948,this movie brings back many fond memories of that time and how we lived back in the 40's and 50's and how special Christmas was for us during this time period. When I watch my Christmas movies,during the seaon,it's not unusual for me to watch this movie twice for the nostalgic effect of when I was a kid in a small Pennsylvania town of about 800 people who all decorated their house's and put up tree's for the season. Even the cars in this movie were still around and the house's looked the same. This movie is a great escape from the sick world we now have to live in. But I seem to have the capability to escape it all when I watch this and my other Christmas movies. Hope other's can do that,too.

This was the perfect opportunity to REALLY do it right. One of the most beloved holiday movies of all-time was having its 30th anniversary, and there's a huge fanbase waiting and willing to pay for the ultimate in a quality remastering of both the video and audio of A Christmas Story. So what do we get? Some modest tweaks to the mono audio and no video improvements at all. It's such a cynical ploy to re-sell the same movie while making the most minimal effort possible to improve it, that it feels like Scut Farkus just took my money.

While I appreciate the added featurette, this 30th Anniversary Edition could have been and should have been SO much better than this. Obviously, this is a five-star+ movie, but I'm being generous in giving this Anniversary edition three stars for the effort in creating it. Thanks so much for taking the time to read my review, and I hope you find it helpful in making a buying decision.

That I didn't go postal at losing an hour and a half on something that would shortly be redundant shows how much I love "A Christmas Story." This 1983 classic is not just a heartwarming little story about a loving (if bickery) family in the dour America of the late 1940s, but a hysterical comedy about what it's like to be a kid at Christmas.

Ralphie Parker's (Peter Billingsley) Christmas wishes are simple: a official Red Ryder, carbine action, two-hundred shot range model air rifle with a compass and a "thing that tells time." But his mom says he'll shoot his eye out. So Ralphie begins a quiet crusade to get it as a present -- he writes an essay on it and even asks Santa, only to get the same terrible reply: "You'll shoot your eye out."

As the days tick down to Christmas -- with no sign of an air rifle -- Ralphie hits other obstacles when he clashes with bullies, says "the mother of all dirty words," and watches his parents battle it out over a tacky "major award" (leg lamp). But there are surprises in store for the Parker family on Christmas morning -- and some of them involve smelly bloodhounds.

Yes, the plot is pretty simple -- it's the delivery that makes it special. It's narrated by an adult Ralphie who offers his slightly sardonic take on everything ("We plunged into the cornucopia quivering with desire and the ecstasy of unbridled avarice"), mingled with a hint of nostalgia. And it's completely tuned in to how kids think, and how a toy can seem like the most important thing in the world.

Fortunately the scriptwriters never condescend to the audience by adding some kind of syrupy message -- after all, real life doesn't work that way. Instead there are all sorts of classic moments -- the leg lamp, Chinese turkey, the terrifying visit to Santa ("HOOOO HOOOO HOOO!"), and Ralphie's fantasies of defending his family with "Ol' Blue" against a bunch of inept, unarmed bandits.

And Jean Shepherd -- the co-writer and narrator of the movie -- deserves especial credit for bringing this movie to life. He covers the movie with a snowstorm of one-liners and hilarious dialogue: "Over the years I got to be quite a connoisseur of soap." "He looks like a pink nightmare!" "Oh FUUUDDDDGGGE!" and others.

Billingsley is a little stiff as Ralphie, but gives the portrayal of this everykid his charming, slightly frenetic best. Melinda Dillon and Darin McGavin are the comic geniuses here, with their slightly kooky but loving parents (one of the highlights is Dillon's "show me how the piggies eat!" scene, and McGavin's revolted response), and there's an array of very convincing bullies and classmates too.

"A Christmas Story" didn't get much notice when it came out in 1983. But now it's one of the quintessential holiday movies, and a must-see at Christmastime. HOOOOO HOOOOO HOOOO...

According to my receiver this newest released version (Nov 5, 2013) of "A Christmas Story" on Blu-ray's audio is in one channel DTS Master HD.  I do notice an improvement in the sound vs. the 2008 "A Christmas Story" on Blu-ray, however it IS still showing only in mono like it did in 2008 (rats).  I enjoyed the added extra feature showcasing the house in Cleveland, OH and gift shop and museum!  Go see this house in Cleveland, OH - you'll love it if you love the movie!  I couldn't believe how the street today looks like it does in the movie, with the exception of the neighboring house missing now (burned down, they say) and some minor painting and minor landscaping changes on other neighboring houses!  Kudos to those involved in refurbishing that house!  - This is being posted on Nov. 7, 2013.

I received this yesterday and did a spot check today. The new BD looks to be the same visually as the earlier BD issue. The DTS sound was clean enough, but as the original mono soundtrack isn't exactly a barn burner, there's no great improvement.

Extras: Being able to access an HD digital version is a plus, and the BD includes a new featurette entitled "Christmas in Ohio: A Christmas Story House," which runs 21:19 and features an all-growed-up Ian Petrella (aka Randy) and Brian Jones, founder of the "A Christmas Story House" in Cleveland. Also, the original recordings by Jean Shepherd that appeared on the 20th-anniversary DVD edition but were missing on the earlier BD have returned. What's still missing are the 20th-anniversary trivia & decoder ring extras from the DVD, which were sort of lame anyway. Watching some of the extras as the participants keep referring to the 20th anniversary of the film (the edition for which the extras were originally filmed) emphasizes how little updating was done for this 30th Anniversary BD Edition.

This 2-disc set includes a DVD as well - it includes both widescreen and full screen versions of the film. The BD contains only the widescreen version. Packaging is a steel book.

Love the movie - I bought this latest issue in the anticipation that I'll be giving my single-BD set away to friends this year (which I did).

For those of us who grew up in the forties and fifties Christmas Story is a wonderful opportunity to travel back to the tinsel-ridden, overloaded-electrical-socket, turkey-roasting Christmases of our youth. Nor will anyone who ever owned a Red Rider BB gun ever forget what a wonderful, liberating tool they were, capable of protecting backyard campers throughout the deepest, darkest nights, and whiling away whatever idle hour might unexpectedly turn up. People who grew up with televisions in the corner of their living room (or worse! in their own bedroom!) will never be able to truly appreciate what the miracle of radio drama meant to us kids in the days before glowing phosphors dominated the world of entertainment. But if they're the slightest bit interested in what it was like to grow up in that ancient time, they could have no better guide to that experience in this film: the costumes, the cars, the family seated around the radio, the teetering Christmas tree, the trip downtown to the big department store, it's all here for you, the good and bad of growing up back then. An indispensable shot of Christmas memories for us oldsters, a massive dose of charm for those too young to remember, "A Christmas Story" has become an iconic part of the Christmas season for all ages.

Simply told, well acted, written to express the life moments that are relevant in every child's life; we have all had an "Official Red Ryder Carbine-Action Two-Hundred-Shot Range Model Air Rifle!" that we, as a child, obsessed over. While that is the main thread of the movie, it's in the side stories of the relationships with parents, teachers, siblings, bullies and friends that makes this such a memorable and universal tale.

I remember when this first aired on TV back in the 80s. The next day I went to work and one of my fellow workers comes up and asks if I saw it. I said "Yeah! It was great! Reminded me of when I was a kid! And the guy who played the father looks just like my Dad!" My friend says "Yeah! Me too! Not that the father looked like my Dad but we had a car just like that. And the town in the film was just like my hometown too." I said 'Yeah mine too!" We could relate to this film more than probably any other movie ever made. It was like looking at a film of our individual youth histories! He grew up in Pontiac and Flint Michigan with all the car factories and I grew up in Allentown/Bethlehem Pennsylvania with Mack Trucks and Bethlehem Steel! We had a huge store in my town named "Hess's", five stories tall and half a city block square. Huge. Everybody shopped "Hess's". It's not there anymore. Sorry to say that. Of course I'm not there anymore either. But it was just like the store in the movie! And the toys were pretty much the same too. I never had a BB gun. An air rifle but no BBs! And my dad worked nights (and days too. he had two jobs!) so I hardly ever saw him growing up. I had a sister, my buddy had two brothers. But the town and the school depicted were just like ours. The film takes place somewhat earlier in time than when he or I were young boys of eight but not by much. We grew up in the 50s. The film takes place either in the late 30s or the early 40s or maybe the later 40s. Can't really tell. My Dad had a 49 Buick Roadmaster! A real tank of a car! Huge. Very simliar to the car in the film. And to top it off Ralphie looks like me when I was eight! Love this movie! But why buy it when TBS runs the film every Christmas for 24 hours? Just had to add it to my collection! Enjoy!

This is a classic movie for Christmas the whole family can share and love. Even the animals (furry children in your family). I just love it and so do my children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and all other little ones that come my way.

I love, love, love this movie. I watch it year round & non stop on Christmas Eve & Christmas Day. My 4 & 5 year old autistic grandchildren are enthralled with this movie.
I can identify with the time period, so it's nostalgia seeing how my Christmases were back in the day. My grandmother had the same type of kitchen sink & washing machine. We would go downtown to see all the stores decorated & visit with Santa.
Ralph is a junior Walter Mitty with all his daydreams/fantasies.
Love the Old Man [who later will be Karl Kolcheck, The Night Stalker]. The mom is overworked & overtired in her "traditional" role as homemaker.
There are just too many favorite scenes to mention. Ralphie's big blue eyes filling with tears & then - he attacks the bully. Yeah, we cheer him on. The bar of soap in Ralph's mouth for swearing. I used all those soaps mentioned & had a couple put into my mouth as well. Grandma didn't mess around.
The kicker scene is Santa saying, "you'll shoot your eye out kid", & pushing an open mouthed, shocked & shattered Ralph down the slide with his foot. Ralph thought that only Santa would understand & could help him get his Red Ryder BB gun.
Watching this movie, it's like I'm being hugged by my grandmother & what I wouldn't give to have that happen right now.
I don't know how popular this movie is with the younger generations, but this movie resonates to my core.
I watch this movie every year at Christmas time. It's great - funny story that makes me smile every time I see it.

This is a movie classic just like A Christmas Carol! Ralphie is a young boy whose obssession is for a Red Ryder beebee gun with a compass in the stock for christmas. However, everyone seems to oppose his wish, even though he leaves not too subtle hints. After all, he's likely to shoot his eye out! This is christmas from a kid's point of view, with enough humor to leave one laughing. From the Major Award to the Scott Farkas affair, these are the times of childhood the way we used to know it when we were kids, when times-- and the things kids wanted were simpler but no less sought after. Does Ralphie get his beebee gun? Will he have to wear that godawful rabbit suit that he got from his benighted aunt? And thanks to the Bumpass' hounds, Chistmas dinner is smiling at us!

How many times do you watch it on Christmas? This movie certainly is a classic. I'm a sucker for flashback films told by a narrator and this is perhaps a primary example of these films. For those of you living under a rock and unfamiliar with this film, it's about a little boy named Ralphie and what he wants for Christmas. The cast is fantastic and it's hilarious without being raunchy. This is how comedies used to be and some would argue should be. No doubt this film is great, but what most people don't know is that there is actually a sequel, with the same narrator, made 11 years later. My Summer Story follows Ralphie and his family the following summer and while the cast is different, the story is equally as good. I'd suggest you check out both films and be careful not to shoot your eye out kid!

For me this is right up there with Its a Wonderful Life for Christmas viewing. This movie is just as rich and charming, great family viewing and like a great cartoon, plenty of subtlety for the grown ups to laugh over.
